item.title: Andy's list of prompt writing principles
item.description: In considering Prompt writing principles for flashcards, one of the more thoughtful resources is Andy Matuschak’s How to write good prompts. According to him, prompts should be: Focused Precise Make clear what the prompt is looking for “poorly written prompts require that you also memorize what the prompt is asking” Consistent Tractable Effortful Encoded thoroughly Attributes / tendencies Similarities and differences Parts and wholes Causes and effects Significance and implications .

item.title: Automate learning with Anki
item.description: In thinking about Desirable features for automating flashcard creation, I’d like to see Anki gently push the boundaries of what we know. @Anton describes it like this: “I tell you something I want to learn about and you generate a spaced repetition program to learn that thing which adapts to my real measured progress.

item.title: Defining Technology
item.description: When we invoke the word “technology”, we’re often implicitly referring to electronics. And while that’s one illustration, it’s far from the word’s main meaning.

item.title: How can LLMs enhance spaced repetition software?
item.description: Spaced repetition software (SRS) is a powerful way to reinforce what we know—I personally use Anki on a daily basis. But it takes time and energy to create questions to review, sometimes up to 2-3x longer than the consumption of content itself.
